Package org.w3c.dom.as

These are the interfaces of the DOM Abstract Schema specification.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
ASAttributeDecl An attribute declaration in the context of a ASObject.
ASContentModel The content model of a declared element.
ASDataType The datatypes supported by DOM AS implementations.
ASDOMBuilder An Abstract Schema parser interface.
ASElementDecl The element name along with the content specification in the context of an ASObject.
ASEntityDecl Models a general entity declaration in an abstract schema.
ASModel To begin with, an abstract schema is a generic structure that could contain both internal and external subsets.
ASNamedObjectMap Objects implementing the ASNamedObjectMap interface are used to represent collections of abstract schema objects that can be accessed by name.
ASNotationDecl This interface represents a notation declaration.
ASObject The ASObject interface is analogous to a Node in , e.g., an element declaration.
ASObjectList The ASObjectList interface provides the abstraction of an ordered collection of AS objects, without defining or constraining how this collection is implemented.
DocumentAS This interface extends the Document interface with additional methods for both document and AS editing.
DOMASWriter A Abstract Schema serialization interface.
DOMImplementationAS This interface allows creation of an ASModel.
 

Exception Summary
ASException Abstract Schemas operations may throw a DOMSystemException as described in their descriptions.
 

Package org.w3c.dom.as Description

These are the interfaces of the DOM Abstract Schema specification.

Important Note: At this time, the DOM L3 abstract schema specifications are cancelled by W3C. We will continue to support the model editing part of the Abstract Schema specification though.

Currently, these interfaces are only available for DTDs, except for ASModel interface that can also be used to access XML Schemas in the XhiveCatalogIf.

  • For XML Schema, you can also take a look at the PSVI interfaces.
  • For DTDs (and XML Schema), you can also take a look at the Validation interfaces (that only have a subset of the functionality, but are to be a W3C specification).

See also the Document Object Model (DOM) Level 3 Abstract Schema Specification of January 14 2002.

The X-Hive/DB DOM implements these interfaces, so you can cast the different kinds of nodes to the relevant interfaces of this package.
